note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: _LAy her aloofe, the Sea grows dangerous,
How it ſpits againſt the clouds, how it capers,
And how the fiery Element frights it back!
There be devils dancing in the aire, I think
I ſaw a Dolphin hang ith hornes of the moone
Shot from a wave: hey day, hey day,
How ſhe kicks and yerks?
Down with'e main Maſt, lay her at hull,
Farle up all her Linnens, and let her ride it out.

sp.speaker: 1 Saylor.
sp.l: Sheele never brook it Maſter.
Shees ſo deep laden, that ſheele buldge;

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: Hang her.
Can ſhe not buffet with a ſtorm a little?
How it toſſes her! ſhe reeles like a Drunkard.

sp.speaker: 2 Saylor.
sp.l: We have diſcovered the Land Sir,
Pray lets make in, ſhee's ſo drunke, elſe,
She may chance to caſt up all her Lading.

sp.speaker: 1 Saylor.
sp.p: Sland in, ſland in, we are all loſt els, loſt and periſht.

sp.speaker: Maſter
sp.l: Steer her a Star boord there.

sp.speaker: 2 Saylor.
sp.l: Beare in with all the Sayle we can, ſee Maſter
See, What a clap of Thunder there is,
What a face of heaven, how dredfully it looks?

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: Thou raſcall, thou fearfull rogue, thou haſt bin praying;
I ſeet in thy face, thou haſt been mumbling,
When we are ſplit you ſlave; is this a time,
To diſcourage our friends with your cold orrizons?
Call up the Boatſwaine; how it ſtorms; holla.

sp.speaker: Boatſwain.
sp.l: What ſhall we doe Maſter?
Caſt over all her lading? ſhe will not ſwimme
An houre elſe; Enter Albert Franvile La-mure Tibalt de pont. Morillat.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: The ſtorm is lowd,
We cannot heare one another,
What's the coaſt?

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: We know not yet; ſhall we make in?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: What comfort Saylers?
I never ſaw, ſince I have known the Sea,
(Which has been this twenty yeers) ſo rude a tempeſt.
In what State are we?

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: Dangerous enough Captain,
We have ſprung five leakes, and no little ones;
Still rage; beſides her ribs are open;
Her rudder almoſt ſpent; prepare your ſelves;
And have good courages, death comes but once,
And let him come in all his frights.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Is't not poſſible,
To make in toth' Land? 'tis here before us.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: Here hard by Sir.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: Death is neerer Gentlemen.
Yet doe not cry, lets dye like men.

sp.speaker: Talbat.
sp.l: Shal's hoyſe the Boat out, Enter Amint.
And goe all at one caſt? the more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.l: You are too haſty Mounſieur,
Do ye long to be ith Fiſh-market before your time?
Hold her up there.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O miſerable Fortune,
Nothing but horrour ſounding in mine eares,
No minute to promiſe to my frighted ſoule.

sp.speaker: Tibat.
sp.l: Peace woman,
We ha ſtorms enough already; no more howling.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Gentle Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Clap this woman under hatches.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Prethee ſpeake mildly to her.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Can no help?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: None that I know.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No promiſe from your goodneſſe?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Am I a God? for heavens ſake ſtoaw this woman.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: Goe: take your gilt Prayer Booke;
And to your buſineſſe; winck and die,
There an old Haddock ſtayes for ye.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Muſt I dye here in all the frights, the terrors,
The thouſand ſeverall ſhapes, death triumphes in?
No friend to councell me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Have Peace ſweet Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No kindreds teares upon me? Oh! my country!
No gentle hand to cloſe mine eyes?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be comforted, heaven has the ſame
Power ſtill, and the ſame mercy.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh! that wave will devour me!

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Carry her down Captaine;
Or by theſe hands, I'le give no more direction,
Let the Ship ſinck or ſwimme; we ha nere better luck,
When we ha ſuch ſtoage as theſe trinkets with us,
Theſe ſweet ſin-breeders; how can heaven ſmile on us,
When ſuch a burthen of iniquity
Lies tumbling like a potion in our Ships belly? Exit.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A way with her, and if ſhe have a Prayer,
That's fit for ſuch an houre, let her ſay't quickly,
And ſeriouſly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Come, I ſee it cleer Lady, come in,
And take ſome comfort. I'le ſtay with ye.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Where ſhould I ſtay? to what end ſhould I hope,
Am I not circled round with miſery?
Confuſions in their full heights dwell about me:
O Mounſier Albert, How am I bound to curſe ye,
If curſes could redeeme me? how to hate ye?
You forc't me from my quiet, from my friends;
Even from their Armes, that were as deere to me,
As day light is, or comfort to the wretched;
You forc't my friends from their peacefull reſt,
Some your relentles ſword gave their laſt groanes;
Would I had there been numbred;
And to fortunes never ſatisfied afflictions,
Ye turn'd my Brother; and thoſe few friends I'd left
Like deſperate creatures, to their own feares
And the worlds ſtubborn pitties: Oh merciles.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: And whether they are wandred to avoyd ye,
Or whether dead and no kind earth to cover 'em;
Was this a lovers part? but heaven has found ye,
And in his lowd voyce, his voyce of thunder,
And in the mutiny of his deep wonders,
He tels ye now, ye weepe too late:

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let theſe tears tell how I honour ye;
Ye know deer Lady, ſince ye were mine,
How truly I have lov'd ye, how ſanctimoniouſly
Obſerv'd your honour; not one laſcivious word,
Not one touch Lady; no, not a hope that might not render me
The unpolluted ſervant of your Chaſtity;
For you I put to Sea, to ſeek your Brother;
Your Captain, yet your ſlave, that his redemption,
If he be living, where the Sunne has circuit,
May expiate your rigor, and my raſhneſſe.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: The Storm grows greater; what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let's in;
And aske heavens mercy; my ſtrong mind yet preſages,
Through all theſe dangers, we ſhall ſee a day yet Exit.
Shall Crown your pious hopes, and my faire wiſhes.

div.stage: Enter Maſter, Saylors, Gentlemen, Boatſwayne and Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: It muſt all over boord.

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: It cleers to Sea-ward maſt.
Fling o're the lading there, and let's lighten her;
All the meat, and the Cakes, we are all gone elſe;
That we may finde her Leakes, and hold her up;
Yet ſave ſome little Bisket for the Lady,
Till we come to the Land.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Muſt my goods over too?
Why honeſt Maſter? here lies all my money;
The money I ha wrackt by uſurie,
To buy new Lands and Lordſhips in new Countryes,
'Cauſe I was baniſht from mine own
I ha been this tweenty yeers a raiſing it.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: Out with it:
The devils are got together by the eares, who ſhall have it;
And here they quarrell in the clouds.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: I am undone Sir:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: And be undone, 'tis better then we periſh.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O ſave one Cheſt of Plate.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A way with it, luſtily Saylors;
It was ſome pawne, that he has got unjuſtly;
Down with it low enough, and let Crabs breed in't;

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Over with the Truncks too. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Take mine and ſpare not;

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We muſt over with all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye throw away my Lordſhip
That I ſold, put it into clothes and neceſſaries,
To goe to Sea with?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Over with it; I love to ſee a Lordſhip ſincke;
Sir you left no Wood upon't to bovy it up;
You might ha ſav'd it elſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am undone for ever;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why we are all undone; would you be only happy?

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Sir you may looſe too.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Thou lieſt; I ha nothing but my skinne,
And my Clothes; my ſword here, and my ſelf;
Two Crowns in my Pocket; two paire of Cards;
And three falſe Dice: I can ſwime like a Fiſh;
Raſcall, nothing to hinder me.

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: In with her of all hands.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, come Captain, ye muſt helpe all;
My life now for the Land,
'Tis high, and rocky, and full of perils;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How ever let's attempt it.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Then cheer luſtily my hearts. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Yes 'tis a Ship, I ſee it now, a tal Ship;
She has wrought luſtily for her deliverance;
Heavens mercy, what a wretched day has here been?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: To ſtill and quiet minds, that knew no miſery,
It may ſeeme wretched, but with us 'tis ordinary;
Heaven has no Storm in ſtore, nor earth no terror,
That can ſeeme new to us.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: 'Tis true Nicuſa; if fortune were determin'd
To be wanton, and would wipe out the ſtories
Of mens miſeries: yet we two living,
We could croſſe her purpoſe; for 'tis impoſſible
She ſhould cure us, we are ſo excellent in our afflictions;
It would be more then glory to her blindnes,
And ſtile her power beyond her pride, to quit us.

sp.speaker: Nicuſa.
sp.l: Doe they live ſtill?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Yes, and make to harbour:

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Moſt miſerable men; I greive their Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: How happy had they been, had the Sea cover'd 'em?
They leap from one calamity to another;
Had they been drown'd, they had ended all their ſorrows.
What ſhowts of joy they make?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Alas poor wretches, had they but once experience
Of this Iſland, they'd turn their tunes to waylings;

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Nay, to curſes.
That ever they ſet foot on ſuch calamities;
Here's nothing but rocks and barrennes,
Hunger, and cold to eat; here's no Vineyards
To cheere the heart of man, no Chriſtall Rivers
After his labour to refreſh his body,
If he be feeble; nothing to reſtore him,
But heavenly hopes; nature that made thoſe remedies,
Dares not come here, nor looke on our diſtreſſes,
For fear ſhe turn wilde like the place and barren.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: O Uncle, yet a little memory of what we were,
'Twill be a little comfort in our calamities;
When we were ſeated in our bleſſed homes,
How happy in our kindreds, in our families,
In all our Fortunes?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Curſe on thoſe French Pirates, that diſplanted us;
That flung us from that happineſſe we found there;
Conſtrain'd us to Sea, to ſave our lives, honours and our riches,
Withall we had, our kinſmen and our jewels,
In hope to finde ſome place free from ſuch robbers,
Where a mighty ſtorme ſeverd our Barkes,
That, where my wife, my daughter
And my noble Ladyes that went with her,
Virgins and loving ſoules, to ſcape thoſe Pirates.

sp.speaker: Nicuſ.
sp.l: They are living yet; ſuch goodneſſe cannot periſh.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt
sp.l: But never to me Cozen;
Never to me againe; what beares their Flag-ſtaves?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: The Armes of France ſure;
Nay, doe not ſtart, we cannot be more miſerable;
Death is a cordial, now, come when it will.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: They get to ſhore a pace, they'le flye as faſt
When once they find the place; what's that which ſwims there?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: A ſtrong young man Sir, with a handſome woman.
Hanging about his Neck.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: That ſhewes ſome honour;
May thy brave charity what ere thou art,
Be ſpoken in a place, that may renown thee,
And not dye here.

sp.speaker: Nicaſa.
sp.l: The Boat it ſeemes turn'd over,
So forced to their ſhifts, yet all are landed,
They're Pirats on my life.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: They will not rob us;
For none will take our miſery for riches:
Come Cozen, let's deſcend and try their pitties;
If we get off, a little hope walkes with us;
If not, we ſhall but load this wretched Iſland
With the ſame ſhadows ſtill that muſt grow ſhorter. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Aminta, Tibalt, Morillat La-mure, Maſter, Franvile, Surgeon, Saylors.

sp.speaker: Tibal.
sp.l: Wet come a ſhore my mates, we are ſafe arrived yet.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Thanks to heavens goodneſſe, no man loſt;
The Ship rides faire to, and her leakes in good plight.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: The weathers turn'd more courteous;
How does my deere?
Alas, how weake ſhe is and wet?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I am glad yet, I ſcapt with life;
Which certain Noble Captain, next to heavens goodneſſe,
I muſt thanke you for, and which is more,
Acknowledge your deer tenderneſſe, your firme love
To your unworthy Miſtreſſe, and recant to
(Indeed I muſt) thoſe harſh opinions,
Thoſe cruell unkind thoughts, I heapt upon ye;
Farther then that, I muſt forget your Injuries.
So farre I am tyde, and fetred to your ſervice,
Beleeve me I will learne to love.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: I thank ye Madam,
And it ſhall be my practiſe to ſerve.
What cheere companions?

sp.speaker: Tibalt.
sp.l: No great cheere Sir, a peece of ſouced Bisket
And halfe a hard egge; for the Sea has taken order;
Being young and ſtrong, we ſhall not ſurfet Captaine.
For mine own part, Ile Dance till I'm dry;
Come Surgeon, out with your Gliſter-pipe,
And ſtricke a Galliard.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What a brave day again;
And what faire weather, after ſo fowle a ſtorme?

sp.speaker: La-mure.
sp.l: I ant pleas'ed the Maſter, he might ha ſeen
This weather, and ha ſav'd our goods.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Never think on em, we have our lives and healths.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: I muſt think on em, and think
'Twas moſt maliciouſly done to undoe me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And me to, I loſt all;
I hant another ſhirt to put upon me, nor Clothes
But theſe poor raggs; I had fifteen faire ſutes,
The worſt was cut upon Taffaty.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am glad you ha loſt, give me thy hand,
Is thy skin whole? art thou not purl'd with ſcabbs?
No Ancient monuments of madam Venus?
Thou haſt a ſuit then will poſe the cunningſt Taylor,
That will never turn faſhion, nor forſake thee,
Till thy executors the wormes uncaſe thee,
They take off glorious ſutes Franvile: thou art happy,
Thou art delivered of em; here are no Brokers;
No Alchymiſts to turn 'em into Mettle;
Nor Leather'd Captaine's with Ladies to adore 'em;
Wilt thou ſee a dogfiſh riſe in one of thy brave doublets,
And tumble like a Tub to make thee merry,
Or an old Haddock riſe with thy hatcht ſword
Thou payd'ſt a hundred Crowns for?
A Mermayd in a mantle of your worſhips,
Or a Dolphin in your double ruffe?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye are merry, but if I take it thus,
If I be foyſted and jeer'd out of my goods.

sp.speaker: La-mure.
sp.l: Nor I, I vow thee.
Nor Maſter nor mate, I ſee your cunning,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O be not angry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Moril.
sp.l: Yes Sir we have reaſon.
And ſome friends I can make.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: What I did Gentlemen, was for the generall ſafety.
If ye ayme at me, I am not ſo tame.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Pray take my councell Gallants.
Fight not till the Surgeon be well,
Hee's damnable Sea-ſick, and may ſpoyle all;
Beſides he has loſt his Fidleſtick, and the beſt
Box of Bores greaſe; why doe you make ſuch faces,
And hand your ſwords?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who would ye fight with? Gentlemen?
Who has done ye wrong? for ſhame be better temper'd.
No ſooner come to give thankes for our ſafeties,
But we muſt raiſe new civill Broyles amongſt us
Inflame thoſe angry powers, to ſhower new vengeance on us?
What can we expect for theſe unmanly murmers,
Theſe ſtrong temptations of their holy pitties,
But plagues in another kind, a fuller, ſo dreadfull,
That the ſinging ſtormes are ſlumbers to it?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Be men and rule your minds;
If you will needs fight Gentlemen,
And thinke to raiſe new riches by your valours,
Have at ye, I have little elſe to doe now
I have ſaid my Prayers; you ſay you have loſt,
And make your loſſe your quarrell,
And grumble at my Captaine here, and the Maſter,
Two worthy perſons; indeed too worthy for ſuch raſcals,
Thou Galloone gallant, and Mamon you
That build on golden mountaines, thou money Maggot;
Come all draw your ſwords, ye ſay ye are miſerable.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, hold good Tibalt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captaine, let me correct em;
I'le make ye ten times worſe, I will not leave em;
For look ye, fighting is as nouriſhing to me as eating,
I was born quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I will not leave em skins to cover em;
Doe ye grumble, when ye are well ye rogues?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Noble Du-pont.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ye have Clothes now: and ye prate.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen, for my ſake be at peace.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Let it become me to make all friends.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have ſtopt our angers Lady.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This ſhewes noble.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: 'Tis well: 'tis very well: there's halfe a Bisket,
Break't amongſt ye all, and thank my bounty,
This is clothes & Plate too; come no more quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But ha! what things are theſe, Enter Sebaſtian and Nicuſa.
Are they humane creatures?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I have heard of Sea-Calves.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are no ſhaddows ſure, they have Leggs and Armes.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.l: They hang but lightly on though.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: How they looke, are they mens faces?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: They have Horſe-Tayles growing to em,
Goodly long maines.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Alas what ſunk eyes they have!
How they are crept in, as if they had been frighted!
Sure they are wretched men.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Where are their Wardrobs?
Looke ye Franvile, here are a cople of Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: They kneele, alas poore ſoules.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What are ye? ſpeake; are ye alive,
Or wandring ſhaddows, that finde no peace on earth,
Till ye reveale ſome hidden ſecret?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: We are men as you are;
Onely our miſeries make us ſeem Monſters.
If ever pitty dwelt in noble hearts;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We underſtand 'em too: pray marke em Gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Sebaſt,
sp.l: Or that heaven is plea'sd with human charity;
If ever ye have heard the name of friendſhip?
Or ſuffered in your ſelves, the leaſt afflictions,
Have gentle Fathers that have bred ye tenderly,
And Mothers that have wept for your misfortunes,
Have mercy on our miſeries.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stand up wretches;
Speak boldly, and have releaſe;

sp.speaker: Nicuſ.
sp.l: If ye be Chriſtians,
And by that bleſſe'd name, bound to releeve us,
Convey us from this Iſland.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Speake; what are ye?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: As you are, Gentle born; to tell ye more,
Were but to number up our own calamities,
And turn your eyes wild with perpetuall weepings;
Theſe many yeers, in this moſt wretched Iſland
We two have liv'd: the ſcorne and game of fortune;
Bleſſe your ſelves from it Noble Gentlemen;
The greateſt plagues, that humane nature ſuffers,
Are ſeated here, wildneſſe, and wants innumerable.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How came ye hither?

sp.speaker: Nicuſ.
sp.l: In a ſhip, as you do, and as you might have been.
Had not heaven preſerv'd ye for ſome more noble uſe;
Wrack't deſperately; our men, and all conſum'd,
But we two; that ſtill live, and ſpin out
The thin and ragged threds of our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Is there no meat above?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Nor meat nor quiet;
No ſummer here, to promiſe any thing;
Nor Autume, to make full the reapers hands;
The earth obdurate to the teares of heaven,
Let's nothing ſhoot but poyſoned weeds.
No Rivers, nor no pleaſant Groves, no beaſts;
All that were made for mans uſe, flye this deſart;
No aëry fowle dares makes his flight over it,
It is ſo ominous.
Serpents, and ugly things, the ſhames of nature,
Roots of malignant taſtes, foule ſtanding waters;
Sometimes we finde a fulſome Sea-root,
And that's a delicate: a Rat ſometimes,
And that we hunt like Princes in their pleaſure;
And when we take a Toad, we make a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: For heavens ſake let's aboord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: D'ee know no farther?

sp.speaker: Nicuſa.
sp.l: Yes, we have ſometimes ſeen the ſhaddow of a place inhabited;
And heard the noyſe of hunters;
And have attempted to finde it, ſo far as a River,
Deep, ſlow, and dangerous, fenced with high Rocks,
We have gone; but not able to atchieve that hazard,
Returne to our old miſeries.
If this ſad ſtory, may diſerve your pitties,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye ſhall aboord with us, we will relieve your miſeries:

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Nor will we be unthankfull for this benefit;
No Gentlemen, wee'le pay for our deliverance;
Look ye that plough the Seas for wealth and pleaſures,
That out-runne day and night with your ambitions,
Looke on thoſe heaps, they ſeeme hard ragged quarries;
Remove 'em, and view 'em fully.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: O heaven, they are Gold and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Be not too haſty, here lies another heape.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: And here another
All perfect gold.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stand farther off, you muſt not be your own carvers;

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: We have ſhares, and deep ones;

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes Sir, wee'le maintain't: ho fellow Saylors.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Stand all to your freedomes;
I'le have all this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I this.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You ſhall be hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: My loſſes ſhall be made good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So ſhall mine, or with my ſword I'le do't;
All that will ſhare with us, aſſiſt us.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captain let's ſet in.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This money will undoe us, undoe us all:

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: This Gold was the overthrow of my happines;
I had command too, when I landed here,
And lead young, high, and noble ſpirits under me,
This curſed Gold entiſing 'em, they ſet upon their Captain,
On me that ow'nd this wealth, & this poor Gentleman,
Gave us no few wounds, forc'd us from our own;
And then their civill ſwords, who ſhould be owners,
And who Lords over all, turn'd againſt their own lives,
Firſt in their rage conſum'd the Ship,
That poor part of the Ship that ſcap't the firſt wracke,
Next their lives by heaps; O be you wiſe and carefull:

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Wee'le ha more: Sirah, come ſhow it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or ten times worſe afflictions then thou ſpeak'ſt of.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, and ye will be Doggs. beats 'em out.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Let me come Captaine:
This Golden age muſt have an Iron ending.
Have at the bunch. he beats 'em off. Exit.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: O Albert; O Gentlemen; O friends. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Come noble Nephew, if we ſtay here, we dye,
Here rides their Ship, yet all are gone toth' ſpoyle,
Let's make a quick uſe.

sp.speaker: Nicuſ.
sp.l: Away deer Uncle.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: This Gold was our overthrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nicuſ.
sp.p: It may now be our happineſſe. Enter Tibalt and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You ſhall have gold: yes, I'le crambe it int'ee;
You ſhall be your own carvers; yes, I'le carve ye.

sp.speaker: Morill.
sp.l: I am ſore, I pray heare reaſon:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I'le heare none.
Covetous baſe mindes have no reaſon;
I am hurt my ſelf; but whil'ſt I have a Legge left,
I will ſo haunt your guilded ſoules; how dee Captain?
Ye bleed apace, curſe on the cauſers ont;
Ye doe not faint?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No, no; I am not ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: D'ee howle, nay, ye deſerve it:
Baſe greedy rogues; come, ſhall we make an end of 'em?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are our country-men, for heavens ſake ſpare em,
Alas, they are hurt enough: & they relent now. Aminta above.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O Captain, Captain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Whoſe voyce is that?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The Ladies.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Look Captain, look; ye are undone: poore Captain,
We are all undone: all, all: we are all miſerable,
Mad wilfull men; ye are undone, your ſhip, your Ship.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Shee's under Sayle and floating;
See where ſhe flies: ſee to your ſhames, you wretches:
Thoſe poor ſtarv'd things, that ſhewed you Gold. La-m. and Franvile go●s up to ſee the Ship.

sp.speaker: 1 Saylor.
sp.l: They have cut the Cables,
And got her out; the tyde too has befrinded em.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Where are the Saylors that kept her?

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: Here, here in the mutiny, to take up mony,
And left no creature, left the Boat a ſhoare too;
This Gold, this damn'd enticing Gold.

sp.speaker: 2 Saylor.
sp.l: How the wind drives her,
As if it vied to force her from our furies?

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Come back good old men:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good honeſt men, come back.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The winds againſt ye, ſpeak lowder;

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have all your Gold againe: they ſee us.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hold up your hands, and kneele,
And houle ye blockheads; they'le have compaſſion on ye;
Yes, yes, 'tis very likely: ye have deſerv'd it,
D'ee look like Doggs now?
Are your mighty courages abated?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I bleed apace Tibalt:

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Retire Sir; and make the beſt uſe of our miſeries.
They but begin now. Enter Aminta;

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Are ye alive ſtill?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yes ſweet.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Help him off Lady;
And wrap him warme, in your Armes,
Here's ſomething that's comfortable; off with him handſomely,
I'le come to ye ſtraight: but vex theſe raſcals a little. Exit Albert Aminta.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh! I am hungry, & hurt, and I am weary.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here's a Peſtle of a Portigue, Sir;
'Tis excellent meat, with ſoure ſauce;
And here's two Chaines, ſuppoſe 'em Sauſages;
Then there wants Muſtar'd.
But the fearefull Surgeon will ſupply ye preſently:

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O for that Surgeon, I ſhall dye elſe.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Faith, there he lies in the ſame pickle too.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: My ſalves, and all my Inſtruments are loſt;
And I am hurt, and ſtarv'd;
Good Sir, ſeeke for ſome Hearbs.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here's Hearbe graceleſſe; will that ſerve?
Gentlemen, will ye goe to Supper!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Where's the meat?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Where's the meat? what a Veale voyce is there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Would we had it Sir, or any thing elſe;

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I would now cut your throat you Dogge,
But that I wo not doe you ſuch a curteſie;
To take you from the benefit of ſtarving.
O! what a comfort will your worſhip have, ſome three dayes hence?
Yea things beneath pitty ſhall be your harbinger;
You muſt not look for down-beds here,
Nor Hangings; though I could wiſh ye ſtrong on's;
Yet here be many lightſome coole Star-chambers,
Open to every ſweet ayre, I'le aſſure ye,
Ready provided for ye, and ſo I'le leave ye;
Your firſt courſe is ſerv'd, expect the ſecond. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A vengeance on theſe Jewels.

sp.speaker: La-m.
sp.l: O! this curſed Gold. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Alas, deere ſoule ye faint.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: You ſpeak the language
Which I ſhould uſe to you; heaven knows, my weaknes
Is not for what I ſuffer in my ſelfe,
But to imagine what you endure, and to what fate
Your cruell Starrs reſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Alb
sp.l: Doe not adde to my afflictions
By your tender pitties; ſure we have chang'd Sexes;
You bear calamity with a fortitude
Would become a man; I like a weake girle ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Amint
sp.l: O! but your wounds,
How fearfully they gape? and every one
To me is a Sepulchre; if I lov'd truly,
Wſe men affirm that true love can doe wonders,
This bath'd in my warme teares, would ſoon be cur'd,
And leave no orifice behind; pray give me leave
To play the Surgeon, and bind em up;
The raw ayre rancles 'em.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet, we want meanes.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Love can ſupply all wants.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What have ye done Sweet?
Oh ſacriledge to beauty: there's no haire
Of theſe pure locks, by which the greateſt King
Would not be gladly bound, and love his Fetters.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: O Albert, I offer this ſacrifice of ſervice
To the Altar of your ſtaid temperance, and ſtill adore it;
When with a violent hand you made me yours,
I curſed the doer: but now I conſider,
How long I was in your power? and with what honour
You entertain'd me? it being ſeldome ſeen,
That youth and heat of b ood could ere preſcribe
Laws to it ſelfe; your goodneſſe is the Lethe,
In which I drown your injuries, and now live
Truly to ſerve ye: how doe you Sir?
Receive you the leaſt eaſe from my ſervice?
If you doe, I am largely recompenc'd.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You good Angels,
That are ingag'd, when mans ability failes,
To reward goodneſſe: look upon this Lady
Though hunger gripes my croaking entrailes,
Yet when I kiſſe theſe rubies, me thinkes
I'm at a banquet a refreſhing banquet;
Speak my bleſſe't one art not hungry?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Indeed I could eat, to beare you com|pany.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Bluſh unkind nature,
If thou haſt power: or being to heare
Thy ſelf, and by ſuch innocence accus'd;
Muſt Print a thouſand kinds of ſhames, upon
Thy various face: canſt thou ſupply a drunkard,
And with a prodigall hand, reach choice of wines,
Ti l he caſt up thy bleſſings? or a glutton,
That robbs the Elements, to ſooth his palat,
And only eats to beget Appetite,
Not to be ſatisfied? and ſuffer here
A Virgin, which the Saints would make their gueſt,
To pine for hunger? ha, if my ſence Hornes within.
Deceive me not, theſe notes take being
From the breath of men; confirme me my Aminta;
Again, this way the gentle wind conveyes it to us,
Heare you nothing?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Yes, it ſeemes free hunters Muſicke;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Still 'tis lowder; and I remember the Portugals
Inform'd us, they had often heard ſuch ſounds,
But ne're could touch the ſhore from whence it came;
Follow me, my Aminta: my good genius,
Shew me the way ſtill; ſtill we are directed;
When we gaine the top of this neer riſing hill Exit. and Enter above.
We ſhall know further.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Curteous Zephyrus
On his dewie wings, carries perfumes to cheer us;
The ayre cleers too;
And now, we may diſcerne another Iſland,
And queſtionleſſe, the ſeat of fortunate men:
O that we could arrive there;

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: No Albert, 'tis not to be hop'd;
This envious Torrent's cruelly interpos'd;
We have no Veſſell that may tranſport us;
Nor hath nature given us wing's to flye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Better try all hazards,
Then periſh here remedileſſe; I feele
New vigor in me, and a ſpirit that dares
More then a man, to ſerve my faire Aminta;
Theſe Armes ſhall be my oares, with which I'le ſwim;
And my zeale to ſave thy innocent ſelfe,
Like wings, ſhall beare me up above the brackiſh waves.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Well ye then leave me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Till now I nere was wretched.
My beſt Aminta, I ſweare by goodneſſe
Tis nor hope, nor feare, of my ſelfe, that invites me
To this extreame; tis to ſupply thy wants; and believe me
Though pleaſure met me in moſt raviſhing formes,
And happineſſe courted me to entertaine her,
I would nor eate nor ſleepe till I return'd
And crown'd thee with my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O but your abſence.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Suppoſe it but a dream; and as you may,
Endeavour to take reſt; and when that ſleep
Deceives your hunger with imagin'd food,
Thinke you have ſent me for diſcovery
Of ſome moſt fortunate Continent, yet unknown,
Which you are to be Queen of.
And now ye Powers that ere heard Lovers prayers,
Or cheriſht pure affection, looke on him
That is your Votary; and make it known
Againſt all ſtops, you can defend your own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How did we loſe Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: When we beliv'd the Stag was ſpent, and would take ſoyle,
The ſight of the blacke Lake which we ſuppos'd
He choſe for his laſt refuge, frighted him more
Then we that did purſue him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That's uſuall; for, death it ſelfe is not ſo terrible
To any beaſt of chaſe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Since we liv'd here, we nere could force one to it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Tis ſo dreadfull,
Birds that with their pinions cleave the Ayre
Dare not flie over it: when the Stag turn'd head,
And we even tyred with labour, Clarinda, as if
She were made of Ayre and Fire,
And had no part of earth in her, eagerly purſu'd him;
Nor need we feare her ſafety, this place yeelds not
Fawnes nor Satyres, or more luſtfull men;
Here we live ſecure,
And have among our ſelves a Common-wealth,
Which in our ſelves begun, with us muſt end.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I there's the miſery.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: But being alone,
Allow me freedome but to ſpeake my thoughts;
The ſtrictneſſe of our Governeſſe, that forbids us
On pain of death the ſight and uſe of men,
Is more then tyranny: for her ſelfe, ſhee's paſt
Thoſe youthfull heats, and feeles not the want
Of that which young mayds long for: and her daughter
The faire Clarinda, though in few yeeres
Improv'd in height and large proportion,
Came here ſo young,
That ſcarce remembring that ſhe had a father,
She never dreames of man; and ſhould ſhe ſee one,
In my opinion, a would appeare a ſtrange beaſt to her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis not ſo with us.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: For my part, I confeſſe it, I was not made
For this ſingle life; nor doe I love hunting ſo,
But that I had rather be the Chace my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: By Venus (out upon me) I ſhould have ſworn
By Diana, I am of thy mind too wench;
And though I have tane an Oath, not alone
To deteſt, but never to thinke of man,
Every houre ſomething tels me I am forſworn;
For I confeſſe imagination helps me ſometimes,
And that's all is left for us to feed on,
We might ſtarve elſe; for if I have any pleaſure
In this life, but when I ſleep, I am a Pagan;
Then from the Courtier to the Country clown,
I have ſtrange viſions.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Viſions Crocale?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Yes, and fine viſions too;
And viſions I hope in dreames are harmleſſe,
And not forbid by our Canons; the laſt night
(Troth tis a fooliſh one, but I muſt tell it)
As I lay in my cabin betwixt ſleeping and waking,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Upon your backe?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: How ſhould a young mayd lie, foole,
When ſhe would be intranc'd?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We are inſtructed; forward I prethee.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Me thought a ſweet young man
In yeeres, ſome twenty, with a downy chin,
Promiſing a future beard, and yet no red one,
Stole ſlylie to my cabin, all unbrac'd,
Tooke me in his armes, and kiſs'd me twenty times,
Yet ſtill I ſlept.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fie; thy lips run over Crocale.
But to the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Lord, what a man is this thought I,
To doe this to a mayd!
Yet then for my life I could not wake.
The youth, a little danted, with a trembling hand
Heav'd up the clothes.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yet ſtill you ſlept.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Yfaith I did; and when, methoughts, he was warm by my ſide,
Thinking to catch him, I ſtretcht out both mine armes;
And when I felt him not, I ſhreekt out,
And wak'd for anger.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Twas a pretty dream. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I, if it had been a true one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But ſtay, what's here caſt oth' ſhore?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tis a man;
Shall I ſhoot him?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: No, no, tis a handſome beaſt;
Would we had more o'the breed; ſtand cloſe wenches,
And let's heare if he can ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Doe I yet live?
Sure it is ayre I breathe; what place is this?
Sure ſomething more then humane keeps reſidence here,
For I have paſt the Stygian gulph,
And touch upon the bleſſed ſhore? tis ſo;
This is the Elizian ſhade; theſe happy ſpirits,
That here enjoy all pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He makes towards us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand, or Ile ſhoot.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Hold, he makes no reſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be not offended Goddeſſes, that I fall
Thus proſtrate at your feet: or if not ſuch,
But Nymphs of Dian's traine, that range theſe groves,
Which you forbid to men; vouchſafe to know
I am a man, a wicked ſinfull man; and yet not ſold
So far to impudence, as to preſume
To preſſe upon your privacies, or provoke
Your Heavenly angers; tis not for my ſelfe
I beg thus poorely, for I am already wounded,
Wounded to death, and faint; my laſt breath
Is for a Virgin comes as neere your ſelves
In all perfection, as whats mortall may
Reſemble things divine. O pitty her,
And let your charity free her from that deſart,
If Heavenly charity can reach to hell,
For ſure that place comes neere it: and where ere
My ghoſt ſhall finde abode,
Eternally I ſhall powre bleſſings on ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By my life I can not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Though I loſe my head for it, nor I. Enter Clarinda.
I muſt pitty him and will.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But ſtay, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What new game have ye found here, ha!
What beaſt is this lies wallowing in his gore?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Keep off.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Wherefore, I pray? I nere turn'd
From a fell Lioneſſe rob'd of her whelps,
And ſhall I feare dead carrion?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O but.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But, what iſt?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is infectious.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Has it not a name?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Yes, but ſuch a name from which
As from the divell your mother commands us flie.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is it a man?

sp.speaker: Cro
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What a brave ſhape it has in death;
How excellent would it appeare had it life!
Why ſhould it be infectious? I have heard
My mother ſay I had a father,
And was not he a man?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Queſtionleſſe Maddam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your fathers too were men?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Without doubt Lady.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And without ſuch it is impoſſible
We could have been.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A ſinne againſt nature to deny it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor can you or I have any hope to be a mother
Without the helpe of men.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Which of you then moſt barbarous, that knew
You from a man had being, and owe to it
The name of parent, durſt preſume to kill
The likeneſſe of that thing by which you are?
Whoſe Arrowes made theſe wounds? ſpeake, or by Dian
Without diſtinction Ile let fly at ye all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not mine.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange to ſee her mov'd thus.
Reſtraine your fury Maddam; had we kild him,
We had but perform'd your mothers command.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But if ſhe command unjuſt and cruell things,
We are not to obey it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: We are innocent; ſome ſtorm did caſt
Him ſhipwrackt on the ſhore, as you ſee, wounded:
Nor durſt we be Surgeons to ſuch
Your mother doth appoint for death.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Weake excuſe; where's pity?
Where's ſoft compaſſion? cruel, and ungratefull!
Did providence offer to your charity
But one poore Subject to expreſſe it on,
And in't to ſhew our wants too; and could you
So careleſly neglect it?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: For ought I know, he's living yet;
And you may tempt your mother, by giving him ſuccour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ha, come neere I charge ye.
So, bend his body ſoftly; rub his temples;
Nay, that ſhall be my Office: how the red
Steales into his pale lips! run and fetch the ſimples
With which my mother heald my arme
When laſt I was wounded by the Bore.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Doe: but remember her to come after ye,
That ſhe may behold her daughters charity.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Now he breathes; Exit Hippolita.
The ayre paſſing through the Arabian groves
Yeelds not ſo ſweet an odour: prethee taſte it;
Taſte it good Crocale; yet I envy thee ſo great a bleſſing;
Tis not ſinne to touch theſr Rubies, is it?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Or thus to live Camelion like?
I could reſigne my eſſence to live ever thus.
O welcome; raiſe him up Gently. Some ſoft hand
Bound up theſe wounds; a womans haire. What fury
For which my ignorance does not know a name,
Is crept into my boſome? But I forget Enter Hipolita.
My pious work. Now if this juyce hath power,
Let it appeare; his eyelids ope: Prodigious!
Two Sunnes breake from theſe Orbes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ha, where am I? what new viſion's this?
To what Goddeſſe doe I owe this ſecond life?
Sure thou art more then mortall:
And any Sacrifice of thanks or duty
In poor and wretched man to pay, comes ſhort
Of your immortall bounty: but to ſhew
I am not unthankfull, thus in humility
I kiſſe the happy ground you have made ſacred
By bearing of your waight.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No Goddeſſe, friend: but made
Of that ſame brittle mould as you are;
One too acquainted with calamities,
And from that apt to pity. Charity ever
Findes in the act reward, and needs no Trumpet
In the receiver. O forbeare this duty;
I have a hand to meet with yours,
And lips to bid yours welcome.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I ſee, that by inſtinct.
Though a young mayd hath never ſeen a man,
Touches have tittulations, and inform her. Enter Roſella.
But here's our Governeſſe;
Now I expect a ſtorme.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Child of my fleſh,
And not of my faire unſpotted mind,
Un-hand this monſter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Monſter, mother?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Yes; and every word he ſpeakes, a Syrens note,
To drowne the careleſſe hearer. Have I not taught thee
The falſhood and the perjuries of men?
On whom, but for a woman to ſhew pity,
Is to be cruell to her ſelfe; the ſoveraignty
Proud and imperious men uſurpe upon us,
We conferre on our ſelves, and love thoſe fetters
We faſten to our freedomes. Have we, Clarinda,
Since thy fathers wrack, ſought liberty,
To loſe it un-compeld? did fortune guide,
Or rather deſtiny, our Barke, to which
We could appoint no Port, to this bleſt place,
Inhabited heretofore by warlike women,
That kept men in ſubjection? did we then
By their example, after we had loſt
All we could love in man, here plant our ſelves,
With execrable oathes never to looke
On man, but as a monſter? and wilt thou
Be the firſt preſident to infringe thoſe vows
We made to Heaven?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Heare me; and heare me with juſtice.
And as ye are delighted in the name
Of mother, heare a daughter that would be like you.
Should all women uſe this obſtinate abſtinence,
You would force upon us; in a few yeeres
The whole world would be peopled
Onely with beaſts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We muſt and will have men.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I or wee'l ſhake off all obedience.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Are ye mad?
Can no perſwaſion alter ye? ſuppoſe
You had my ſuffrage to your ſute;
Can this Shiprackt wretch ſupply them all?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hear me great Lady?
I have fellowes in my miſery, not far hence,
Divided only by this helliſh River,
There live a company of wretched men
Such as your charity may make your ſlaves;
Imagine all the miſeries mankind
May ſuffer under: and they groane beneath em.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But are they like to you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Speak they your Language?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Are they able, luſty men?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They were good Ladyes;
And in their May of youth of gentle blood,
And ſuch as may deſerve ye; now cold and hunger
Hath leſſen'd their perfection: but reſtor'd
To what they were, I doubt not they'l appeare
Worthy your favours.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is a bleſſing
We durſt not hope for.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Deere Mother, be not obdurate.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Hear then my reſolution: and labour not
To add to what i'le grant, for 'twill be fruitleſſe,
You ſhall appear as good angels to theſe wretched men;
In a ſmall Boat wee'l paſſe o're to 'em;
And bring 'em comfort: if you like their perſons,
And they approve of yours: for wee'l force nothing;
And ſince we want ceremonies,
Each one ſhall chooſe a husband, and injoy
His company a month, but that expird
You ſhall no more come neer 'em; if you prove fruitful,
The Males yee ſhall return to them, the Females
We will reſerve our ſelves: this is the utmoſt,
Yee ſhall 'ere obtaine: as yee think fit;
Yee may diſmiſſe this ſtranger,
And prepare to morrow for the journey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come Sir, will ye walke?
We will ſhew ye our pleaſant Bowers,
And ſomething yee ſhall find to cheer your heart.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent Lady;
Though 'twill appear a wonder one neer ſtarv'd
Should refuſe reſt and meat, I muſt not take
Your noble offer: I left in yonder deſart
A Virgin almoſt pind.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Shee's not your wife?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No Lady, but my ſiſter (tis now dangerous
To ſpeak truth) to her I deeply vow'd
Not to taſt food or reſt, if fortune brought it me,
Till I bleſs'd her with my returne: now if you pleaſe
To afford me an eaſie paſſage to her,
And ſome meat for her recovery,
I ſhall live your ſlave: and thankfully
Shee ſhall ever acknowledge her life at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You plead ſo well, I can deny ye nothing;
I my ſelfe will ſee you furniſht;
And with the next Sun viſit and relieve thee.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yee are all goodneſſe— Exit.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Oh! what a tempeſt have I in my ſtomack?
How my empty guts cry out? my wounds ake,
Would they would bleed again, that I might get
Something to quench my thirſt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Lamure, the happineſſe my doggs had
When I kept houſe at home! they had a ſtorehouſe,
A ſtourehouſe of moſt bleſſed bones and cruſts,
Happy cruſts: Oh! how ſharp hunger pinches me? Exit Franvile

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O my importunate belly I have nothing
To ſatisfie thee; I have ſought,
As far as my weake legs would carry me,
Yet can find nothing: neither meat nor water;
Nor any thing thats nouriſhing,
My bellies grown together like an empty ſachell. Enter Franvile.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How now what news?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Haſt any meat yet?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not a bit that I can ſee;
Here be goodly quarries, but they be cruell hard
To gnaw: I ha got ſome mud, we'l eat it with ſpoons,
Very good thick mud: but it ſtinkes damnably;
Ther's old rotten trunks of Trees to,
But not a leafe nor bloſſome in all the Iſland.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How it looks?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: It ſtinkes too.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: It may be poyſon.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let it be any thing;
So I can get it down: why man,
Poyſon's a princely diſh.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Haſt thou no Bisket?
No crumbs left in thy pocket: here's my dublet,
Give me but three ſmall crumbes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not for three Kingdoms,
If I were maſter of 'em: Oh Lamure,
But one poore joynt of Mutton: we ha ſcornd (man)

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Thou ſpeakeſt of paradiſe,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or but the ſnuffes of thoſe healths,
We have lewdly at midnight flang away.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ah! but to lick the Glaſſes. En. Surgeon

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here comes the Surgeon: what
Haſt thou diſcovered? ſmile, ſmile, and comfort us.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I am expiring;
Smile they that can: I can find nothing Gentlemen,
Here's nothing can be meate without a miracle.
O that I had my boxes and my lints now,
My ſtupes, my tents, and thoſe ſweet helps of nature,
What dainty diſhes could I make of'em.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Haſt neer an old ſuppoſitory?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Oh would I had ſir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Or, but the paper where ſuch a Cordiall
Potion or Pils hath bin entombd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Or, the bleſt bladder where a cooling gliſter

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Haſt thou no ſearcloths left?
Nor any old poulties?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We care not to what it hath bin miniſtred.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Sure I have none of theſe dainties Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wher's the great Wen
Thou cutſt from Hugh the ſaylers ſhoulder?
That would ſerve now for a moſt Princely banquet.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I, if we had it Gentlemen.
I flung it over-board, ſlave that I was;

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A moſt unprovident villaine.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: If I had any thing that were but ſupple now!
I could make ſallads of your ſhoos Gentlemen,
And rare ones: any thing unctious.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I and then we might fry the ſoales 'ith Sun.
The ſoales would make a ſecond diſh.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Or, ſouce 'em in the ſalt-water,
An inner ſoale well ſouc'd. En. Aminta

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here comes the Woman;
It may be ſhe has meat and may relieve us,
Lets withdraw, and marke and then be ready,
Shee'l hide her ſtore els, and ſo cozen us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How weary and how hungry am I,
How feeble and how faint is all my body?
Mine eyes like ſpent Lamps glowing out grow heavy,
My ſight forſaking me and all my ſpirits,
As if they heard my paſſing bell go for me,
Pull in their powers and give me up to deſtiny,
Oh! for a little water: a little little meat,
A little to relieve me ere I periſh:
I had whole floods of tears awhile that noriſht me,
But they are all conſum'd for thee deere Albert;
For thee they are ſpent, for thou art dead;
Mercileſſe fate hath ſwallowd thee.
Oh — I grow heavy: ſleep is a ſalve for miſery;
Heaven look on me, and either take my life,
Or make me once more happy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Hee's faſt aſleep already,
Why ſhould ſhee have this bleſſing, and we wake ſtill,
Wake to our wants?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: This thing hath bin our overthrow,
And all theſe biting miſchieves that fall on us
Are come through her means.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: True we were bound yee all know,
For happy places and moſt fertill iſlands,
Where we had conſtant promiſes of all things,
Shee turn'd the Captaines minde,
And muſt have him go in ſearch, I know not of who,
Nor to what end: of ſuch a foole her brother,
And ſuch a coxcomb her kinſman, and we muſt put in every where,
She has put us in now yfaith.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why ſhould we conſume thus, and ſtarve,
Have nothing to relieve us;
And ſhee live there that bred all our miſeries,
Unroſted or unſod?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I have read in ſtories.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Of ſuch reſtoring meates,
We have examples;
Thouſand examples and allow'd for excellent;
Women that have eate their Children,
Men their ſlaves, nay their brothers: but theſe are nothing;
Husbands devoured their wives (they are their chattels,)
And of a Schoolemaſter that in a time of famine,
Powdered up all his Schollers.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Shee's young and tydie,
In my conſcience ſhee'l eate delicatly;
Juſt like young Porke a little lean,
Your opinion Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I think ſhee may be made good meat.
But look we ſhall want Salt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tuſh, ſhe needs no powdering,

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I grant ye;
But to ſuck out the humorous parts: by all means,
Lets kill her in a chafe, ſhee'l eat the ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lets kill her any way: and kill her quickly,
That we might be at our meat.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: How if the Captaine?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Talk not of him, hee's dead, and the reſt famiſh'd.
Wake her Surgeon, and cut her throate,
And then divide her, every man his ſhare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Shee wakes her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Holy and good things keep me!
What cruell dreames have I had! who are theſe?
O they are my friends; for heavens ſake Gentlemen
Give me ſome food to ſave my life: if ye have ought to ſpare;
A little to relieve me: I may bleſſe yee;
For weake and wretched, ready to periſh
Even now I die.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You'l ſave a labour then,
You bred theſe miſeries, and you ſhall pay for't;
We have no meat, nor where to have we know not,
Nor how to pull our ſelves from theſe afflictions,
We are ſtarv'd too, famiſht, all our hopes deluded;
Yet ere we die thus, wee'l have one deinty meale.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Shall I be with ye Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Yes mary ſhall yee: in our bellies Lady.
We love you well —

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: What ſaid you ſir?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Mary wee'l eat your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You that have buried us in this baſe Iſland,
Wee'l bury ye in a more noble Monument.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Will ye ſay your prayers, that I may perform Lady?
We are wondrous ſharp ſet; come Gentlemen,
Who are for the hinder parts?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I. Fran. I.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Be patient;
They will not fall to every mans ſhare.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O hear me;
Hear me ye barbarous men.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Be ſhort and pithy,
Our ſtomakes cannot ſtay a long diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: And be not fearfull,
For i'le kill ye daintily.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Are ye not Chriſtians?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Why, do not Chriſtians eat women? En. Tibalt Maſter, Saylors.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Eat one another? tis moſt impious.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Come come.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Oh, help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The Ladies voyce! ſtand off ſlaves,
What do you intend villains?
I have ſtrength enough left me, if you abuſe this ſoule,
To —

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They would have raviſht her upon my life,
Speak, how was it Lady?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Forgive 'em, 'twas their hungers.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ha, their hungers!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They would have eaten her.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O dam'd villains; ſpeak, is it true?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I confeſſe an appetite.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: An appetite, i'le fit ye for an appetite.
Are ye ſo ſharp ſet that her fleſh muſt ſerve you?
Murther's a maine good ſervice with your worſhips;
Since ye would be ſuch devils,
Why did you not begin with one another handſomly;
And ſpare the woman to beget more food on?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You ſhall grow mumey raſcals;
I'le make you fall to your brawnes and your buttocks,
And worry one another like keen bandoggs.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Good ſir be mercifull.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You ſhall know what tis to be damnd Canibals.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my beſt friend! Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Alas poor heart! here,
Here's ſome meat and ſoveraigne drink to eaſe you,
Sit down gentle Sweet.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am bleſt to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sir, not within forty foot of this food,
If you do dogs!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Oh, Captain Captain, Captain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have meat all of you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Captain, hear me firſt: hark,
Tis ſo inhumane! I would not ha the aire corrupted with it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O barbarous men! ſit down Dupont,
Good Maſter and honeſt Saylors.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: But ſtand you off,
And waite upon our charity; i'le wait on you els;
And touch nothing but what's flung t'ee; as if you were dogs;
If you do, i'le cut your fingers; friends
I'le ſpoyle your carving.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: There wretches there.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Eat your meate handſomly now,
And give Heaven thanks.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There's more bread.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: See they ſnarle like dogs;
Eat quietly you raſcals, eat quietly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There is drink too.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Come, come, i'le fill you each your cups,
Ye ſhal not ſurfet.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: And what have you diſcovered?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sweet, a paradiſe,
A paradiſe inhabited with Angels,
Such as you are: their pitties makt 'em angels,
They gave me theſe viands, and ſupply'd me
With theſe pretious drinks.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Shall not we ſee 'em?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Yes, they will ſee you
Out of their charities, having heard our ſtory
They will come, and comfort us, come preſently
We ſhall no more know wants nor miſeries.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Are they all women?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All, and all in love with us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do not miſtake: in love with our misfortunes,
They will cheriſh and relieve our men.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Do you ſhrug now,
And pull up your noſes? you ſmell comfort,
See they ſtretch out their Legs, like dottrels,
Each like a new Saint Dennis.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Deere Miſtris,
When you would name me, and the women hear,
Call me your brother, you i'le call my ſiſter,
And pray obſerve this all—
Why do you change colour ſweet.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Eating too much meat.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sawce with jealouſie;
Fie, fie deer ſaint, yfaith ye are too blame, En. Roſſellia, Clarinda, Crocale, Hipollitta Iuletta.
Are ye not here? here fixt in my heart?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hark, hark;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They are come, ſtand ready, & look nobly,
And with all humble reverence receive 'em,
Our lives depend upon their gentle pitties,
And death waits on their anger.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Sure they are Fairies.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Be they devils: devils of fleſh and blood;
After ſo long a Lent, and tedious voyage
To me they are angels.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O for ſome Eringoes!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Potatoes, or Cantharides.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Peace you rouges that buy abilities of your 'pothecaries,
Had I but took the diet of green Cheeſe,
And Onions for a month, I could do wonders.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Are theſe the Jewels you run mad for?
What can you ſee in one of theſe
To whom you would vouchſafe a gentle touch?
Can nothing perſwade you
To love your ſelves, and place your happineſſe
In cold and chaſt enbraces of each other.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: This is from the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We had your grant to have them as they were.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tis a beauteous Creature,
And to my ſelfe, I do appeare deform'd,
When I conſider her, and yet ſhee is
The ſtrangers ſiſter; why then ſhould I fear?
Shee cannot prove my rivall.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: VVhen you repent,
That you refus'd my councell, may it add
To your afflictions, that you were forward;
Yet leap'd into the Gulfe of your misfortunes,
But have your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Now ſhe makes to us.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am inſtructed, but take heed Albert,
You prove not falſe;

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are your own aſſurance,
And ſo acquainted with your own perfections,
That weak doubts cannot reach you; therefore fear not.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: That you are poor and miſerable men,
My eyes inform me: that without our ſuccours,
Hope cannot flatter you to dream of ſafety;
The preſent plight you are in, can reſolve you
That to be mercifull, is to draw near
The Heavenly eſſence: whether you wilbe
Thankfull, I do not queſtion; nor demand
VVhat country bred you, what names, what maners;
To us it is ſufficient we relieve
Such as have ſhapes of men: and I command you,
As we are not ambitious to know
Farther of you, that on paine of death
You preſume not to enquire what we are
Or whence deriv'd.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: In all things we obey you,
And thankfully we ever ſhall confeſſe
Our ſelves your creatures.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: You ſpeak as becomes you;
Firſt then and willingly deliver up
Thoſe weapons we could force from you▪

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: VVe lay 'em down
Moſt gladly art your feet.

sp.speaker: Tih.
sp.l: I have had many a combat with a tall wench;
But never was diſarm'd before.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: And now hear comfort,
Your wants ſhalbe ſupplied, and though it be
A debt women may challenge to be ſued to,
Eſpecially from ſuch they may command;
VVe give up to you that power, and therefore
Freely each make his choyce.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then here I fix.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay, ſhe is mine: I eyed her firſt.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: This mine.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Stay good raſcals;
You are too forward, ſir Gallant,
You are not giving order to a Taylor
For the faſhion of a new ſuit;
Nor are you in your warehouſe, maſter Merchant,
Stand back and give your betters leave: your betters;
And grumble not; if ye do, as I love meat
I will ſo ſwinge the ſalt itch out on you.
Captaine, Maſter and the reſt of us,
That are brothers and good fellows: we have bin
Too late by the ears: and yet ſmart for our follies;
To end therefore all future emulation: if you pleaſe,
To truſt to my election, you ſhall ſay,
I am not partiall to my ſelfe; I doubt not
Give content to all.

sp.speaker: All,
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then but obſerve how learned and diſcreetly,
I wil proceed, and as a skilfull Doctor
In all the quirks belonging to the game;
Read over your complexions: for you Captaine
Beinſt firſt in place and therefore firſt to be ſerv'd,
I give my judgement thus, for your aſpect
Y'are much inclind to melancholy: and that tels me
The ſullen Saturne had predominance
At your nativity, a malignant planet,
And if not qualified by a ſweet conjunction
Of a ſoft and ruddy wench born under Venus,
It may prove fatall: therefore to your armes,
I give this roſe-cheekt Virgin.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To my wiſh;
Till now I never was happy.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Nor I accurs'd.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Maſter, you are old;
Yet love the game, that I perceive too,
And if not well ſpurd up, you may prove ruſty;
Therefore to help ye here's a Bradamanta,
Or I am coſend in my calculation.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: A poore old man alloted to my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt have two;
Nay I think twenty: but fear not wench,
Though he be old he's tough: look on's making,
Hee'l not fayle I warant thee.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: A merry fellow,
And were not man a creature I deteſt,
I could indure his company.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Here's a fayre heard of Does before me,
And now for a barren one:
For though I like the ſport: I do not love
To Father children: like the grand ſignior,
Thus I walk in my Seraglio,
And vew 'em as I paſſe: then draw I forth
My handkercher, and having made my choyce,
I thus beſtow it.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: On me.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: On you: now my choyce is made;
To it you hungry raſcals.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: As I love goodneſſe,
It makes me ſmile ith height of all my feares.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What a ſtrong contention you may behold
Between my Mothers mirth and anger.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Nay, no coyneſſe: be miſtriſſe of your word,
I muſt and will enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Be adviz'd foole: alas I am old;
How canſt thou hope content from one that's fifty.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Never talke on't;
I have known good ones at threeſcore and upwards;
Beſides the weathers hot: and men
That have experience, fear feavers:
A temperate diet is the only phyſick,
Your Julips nor Gujacum prunello's,
Champhire pils, nor Goord-water,
Come not neer your old woman;
Youthfull ſtomackes are ſtill craving,
Though their be nothing left to ſtop their mouths with;
And believe me I am no frequent giver of thoſe bounties:
Laugh on: laugh on: good Gentlemen do,
I ſhall make holiday and ſleep, when you
Dig in the mines till your hearts ake.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: A mad fellow;
Well Sir, i'le give you hearing: and as I like
Your wooing and diſcourſe: but I muſt tell ye ſir,
That rich widdowes look for great ſums in preſent,
Or aſſurances of ample joynters.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: That to me is eaſie,
For inſtantly i'le do it, hear me comrades.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What ſayſt thou Tibalt?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Why, that to woe a wench with empty hands
Is no good heraldy, therefore lets to the gold,
And ſhare it equally: 'twill ſpeak for us
More then a thouſand complements or cringes,
Ditties ſtolne from Patrick, or diſcourſe from Ovid,
Beſides 'twill beget us reſpect,
And if ever fortune friend us with a Barque,
Largly ſupply us with all proviſion.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well advis'd, defer it not.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Are ye all contented.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are▪

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Lets away then,
Straight wee'l returne,
And you ſhall ſee our riches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Since I know what wonder and amazement was,
I neer was ſo tranſported.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why weep ye gentle mayd?
There is no danger here to ſuch as you;
Baniſh fear: for with us I dare promiſe,
You ſhall meet all courteous entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: We eſteem our ſelves moſt happy in you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And bleſſe fortune that brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hark in your eare;
I love you as a friend already,
Ere long you ſhall call me by a neerer name,
I wiſh your brother well: I know you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I to my griefe I do;
Alas good Ladies, there is nothing left me
But thanks to pay ye with. Enter Albert, Tibalt, and the reſt with trea|ſure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That's more
Then yet you ſtand ingaged for.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: So ſoon returnd!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hear: ſee the idoll of the Lapidary.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Theſe Pearls for which the ſlaviſh Negro
Dives to the bottome of the Sea.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To get which the induſtrious Merchant
Touches at either pole.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The never-fayling purchaſe
Of Lordſhips and of honors.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The worlds Miſtris,
That can give every thing to the poſſeſſors.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: For which the Saylors ſcorn tempeſtuous winds,
And ſpit defiance in the Sea.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Speak Lady: look we not lovely now?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Yes: yes, O my Starrs
Be now for ever bleſt, that have brought
To my revenge theſe robbers; take your arrowes,
And nayle theſe monſters to the earth.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What mean ye Lady?
In what have we offended?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: O my daughter!
And you companions with me in all fortunes,
Look on theſe Caskets and theſe Jewels
Theſe were our own, when firſt we put to Sea
With good Sebaſtian: and theſe the Pyrats
That not alone depriv'd him of this treaſure,
But alſo took his life.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Part of my preſent
I well remember was mine own.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And theſe were mine.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Sure, I have worne this Jewel.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Wherefore do ye ſtay then,
And not performe my command?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O Heaven!
What cruell fate purſues us.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: I am well enough ſerv'd,
That muſt be offring jointures, Jewels,
And precious ſtones more then I brought with me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Why, ſhoote ye not?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Heare me deere Mother;
And when the greateſt cruelty, is Juſtice,
Do not ſhew mercy: death to theſe ſtarv'd wretches
Is a reward, not puniſhment: let 'em live
To undergoe the full weight of your diſpleaſure.
And that they may have ſence to feel the torments
They have deſerv'd: allow 'm ſome ſmall pittance,
To linger out their tortures.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Tis well counſell'd.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: And wee'l follow it;
Heare us ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Peace dogs.
Bind 'em faſt: when fury hath given way to reaſon,
I will determine of their ſufferings,
Which ſhall be horrid. Vengeance, though ſlow pac'd,
At length oretakes the guilty; and the wrath
Of the incenſed powers will fall moſt ſure
On wicked men, when they are moſt ſecure. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: Heres nothing, ſir, but poverty and hunger;
No promiſe of inhabitance; neither tract of Beaſt,
Nor foot of man: we have ſearcht
All this Rocky deſart, yet cannot diſcover any aſſurance
Here is or hath been ſuch men.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: Not a relique of any thing they wore;
Nor marke left by 'em, either to finde reliefe,
Or to warne others from the like misfortune.
Believe it, theſe fellows are both falſe,
And to get a little ſuccour in their miſery,
Have fram'd this cunning tale.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The ſhip, I know, is French, and own'd by Pirats,
If not by Albert my arch enemy.
You told me too there was a woman with 'em.
A young and handſome woman.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: There was ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And ſuch and ſuch young gallants.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: We told ye true ſir,
That they had no means to quit this Iſland.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And that amidſt their mutiny to ſave your lives
You got their ſhip.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: All is moſt certaine ſir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Where are they then? where are theſe men
Or woman? we are landed where your faiths
Did aſſure us we could not miſſe their ſights.
For this news we tooke ye to our mercy,
Reliev'd ye, when the furious Sea and famine
Strove which ſhould firſt devoure ye;
Cloath'd, and cheriſht ye; us'd ye as thoſe ye ſay ye are.
Faire Gentlemen, now keep your words,
And ſhew us this company, your own free pitties ſpoke of;
Theſe men ye left in miſery; the woman.
Men of thoſe noble breedings you pretend to.
Should ſcorn to lie, or get their food with falſhood;
Come, direct us.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Alaſſe ſir, they are gone,
But by what means or providence, we know not.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: Was not the Captain
A fellow of a fiery, yet brave nature,
A middle ſtature, and of brown complexion?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: He was ſir.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: 'Twas Albert,
And my poore wretched ſiſter.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: Twas he certain,
I ha been at Sea with him; many times at Sea.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Come ſhew us theſe men;
Shew us preſently, and do not dally with us.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: We left 'em here; what ſhould we ſay, ſir?
Here in this place.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: The earth cannot ſwallow 'em;
They have no wings, they cannot fly ſure.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: You told us too
Of heapes of treaſure, and of ſums conceald,
That ſet their hearts a fire; we ſee no ſuch thing,
No ſuch ſign; what can ye ſay to purge ye?
What have ye done with theſe men?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: We, ſir?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: You ſir;
For certain I believe ye ſaw ſuch people.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: By all that's good,
By all that's pure and honeſt,
By all that's holy.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: I dare not credit ye,
Ye have ſo abuſ'd my hope, that now I hate ye.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: Lets put 'em in their ragged clothes again Captain,
For certain they are knaves, lets e'en deliver 'em
To their old fruitfull Farm; here let 'em walk the Iſland.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: If ye do ſo, we ſhall curſe your mercies.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Rather put us to Sea again.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Not ſo.
Yet this Ile do, becauſe ye ſay ye are Chriſtians,
Though I hardly credit it: bring in the boat,
And all aboord again, but theſe two wretches;
Yet leave 'em four daies meat. If in that time,
(For I will ſearch all nookes of this ſtrange Iſland)
I can diſcover any tract of theſe men,
Alive or dead, Ile beare ye off, and honour ye;
If not, ye have found your graves; ſo farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: That goodnes dwels above, & knows us innocent,
Comfort our lives, and at his pleaſure quit us.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Come couſin, come; old time will end our ſtory:
But no time (if we end well) ends our glory. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Roſſella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, Juletta.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Uſe 'em with all the auſterity that may be,
They are our ſlaves; turn all thoſe pitties,
Thoſe tender reluctations that ſhould become your ſex,
To ſtern anger; and when ye look upon 'em,
Looke with thoſe eyes that wept thoſe bitter ſorrows,
Thoſe cruelties ye ſufferd by their rapines.
Some five daies hence that bleſſed houre comes,
Moſt happy to me, that knit this hand to my deare huſbands,
And both our hearts in mutuall bands.
That houre Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What of that houre?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Why, on that houre daughter,
And in the height of all our celebrations,
Our deere remembrances of that deere man,
And thoſe that ſuffered with him, our faire kinſmen,
Their lives ſhall fall a ſacrifice to vengeance,
Their lives that ruind his; tis a full juſtice.
I will looke glorious in their bloods;
And the moſt Noble ſpirit of Sebaſtian,
That periſht by the pride of theſe French Pirates,
Shall ſmile in Heaven, and bleſſe the hand that kild 'em.
Looke ſtrictly all unto your priſoners;
For he that makes a ſcape beyond my vengeance,
Or entertaines a hope by your faire uſage;
Take heed, I ſay, ſhe that deceives my truſt,
Again take heed: her life, and thats but light neither;
Her life in all the tortures my ſpirit can put on.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We ſhall be carefull.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Do ſo. Exit Roſſella.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your are angry mother, and ye are old too,
Forgetting what men are: but we ſhall temper ye.
How fare your priſoners, Ladies? in what forms
Do they appeare in their afflictions?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mine fare but poorly;
For ſo I am commanded: tis none of their fault.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Of what ſort are they?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They ſay they are Gentlemen.
But they ſhew Mungrels.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How do they ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Faith like boyes;
They are fearfull in all fortunes; when I ſmile
They kneele, and beg to have that face continued;
And like poore ſlaves, adore the ground I goe on.
When I frown, they hang their moſt dejected heads,
Like fearfull ſheephounds; ſhew 'em a cruſt of bread
Theyl Saint me preſently, and skip like Apes
For a ſup of Wine. Ile whip 'em like hackneys,
Saddle 'em, ride 'em, do what I will with 'em.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tuſh, theſe are poore things.
Have they names like Chriſtians?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Very faire names: Franvile, Lamure, and Morillat;
And brag of great kindreds too. They offer very handſomely,
But that I am a foole, and dare not venture.
They are ſound too i'my conſcience,
Or very neere upon 't.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fy, away foole.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They tell me
If they might be brought before you,
They would reveale things of ſtrange conſequence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Their baſe poore feares.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I, that makes me hate 'em too;
For if they were but manly to their ſufferance,
Sure I ſhould ſtrain a point or two.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: An houre hence Ile take a view of 'em,
And heare their buſineſſe. Are your men thus too?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Mine? No gentle Maddam, mine were not caſt
In ſuch baſe molds; afflictons, tortures,
Are names and natures of delight, to my men;
All ſorts of cruelties they meet like pleaſures.
I have but two; the one they call Du-pont,
Tibalt Du-pont; the other the ſhip-maſter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have they not lives, and feares?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Lives they have Maddam;
But thoſe lives never linkt to ſuch companions
As feares or doubts.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Uſe 'em Nobly;
And where you finde fit ſubjects for your pitties
Let it become ye to be courteous;
My mother will not alwaies be thus rigorous.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: Mine are Saylors Maddam,
But they ſleep ſoundly, and ſeldom trouble me, unleſſe it be when
They dream ſometimes of fights and tempeſts;
Then they rore and whiſtle for Cans of Wine,
And down they fling me; and in that rage,
(For they are violent fellows) they play ſuch reaks.
If they have meat, they thank me;
If none, they heartily deſire to be hangd quickly.
And this is all they care.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Look to 'em diligently, and where your pitties tels ye
They may deſerve, give comfort.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come hither, be not frighted; Enter Aminta,
Think not ye ſteale this liberty, for we give it,
Your tender innocence aſſures me, Virgin,
Ye had no ſhare in thoſe wrongs theſe men did us;
I finde ye are not hardned in ſuch miſchieves.
Your brother was miſ-led ſure,
Foully miſ-led.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: How much I feare theſe pities!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Certain he was, ſo much I pity him;
And for your ſake, whoſe eyes plead for him;
Nay, for his own ſake.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: For I ſee about him
Women have ſubtill eyes, and look narrowly;
Or I am much abuſd: many faire promiſes;
Nay beyond thoſe, too many ſhadowed vertues.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I think he is good.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I aſſure my ſelfe he will be;
And out of that aſſurance take this comfort,
For I perceive your feare hath much dejected ye.
I love your brother.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Maddam.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, do not take it for a dreamt of favour,
That comforts in the ſleepe, and awake vaniſhes;
Indeed I love him.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do ye indeed?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You doubt ſtill, becauſe ye feare his ſafety;
Indeed he is the ſweeteſt man I ere ſaw;
I think the beſt. Ye may heare without bluſhes,
And give me thanks, if ye pleaſe, for my curteſie.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Maddam, I ever muſt;
Yet witneſſe Heaven, they are hard pul'd from me.
Believe me, Maddam, ſo many imperfections I could find,
(Forgive me Grace for lying) and ſuch wants,
(Tis to an honeſt uſe) ſuch poverties,
Both in his main proportion, and his mind too;
There are a hundred handſomer; (I lie leudly)
Your noble uſage, Maddam, hath ſo bound me to ye,
That I muſt tell ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come tell your worſt.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: He is no husband for ye.
I think ye mean in that fayr way.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye have hit it.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I am ſure ye have hit my heart.
You will finde him dangerous, Maddam;
As fickle as the flying ayre, proud, jealous,
Soon glutted in your ſweets, and ſoon forgetfull;
I could ſay more, and tell ye I have a brother,
Another brother, that ſo far excels this,
Both in the ornaments of man, and making.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If you were not his ſiſter, I ſhould doubt ye mainly;
Doubt ye for his love, ye deale ſo cunningly.
Do not abuſe me, I have truſted ye with more then life,
With my firſt love; be carefull of me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: In what uſe, Maddam?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: In this Lady,
Speak to him for me, you have power upon him;
Tell him I love him, tell him I dote on him.
It will become your tongue.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Become my grave.
O fortune, O curſed fortune.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tell him his liberty,
And all thoſe with him; all our wealth and Jewels.
Good ſiſter, for Ile call ye ſo.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I ſhall Lady,
Even die, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Here's Meat and Wine, pray take it,
And there he lies; give him what liberty you pleaſe;
But ſtill conceald. What pleaſure you ſhall pleaſe, ſiſter.
He ſhall nere want again. Nay, ſee an you'l take it;
Why do you ſtuddy thus?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: To avoyd miſchiefes, if they ſhould happen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Goe and be happy for me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O blind fortune;
Yet happy thus far, I ſhall live to ſee him,
In what ſtrange deſolation lives he here now?
Sure this Curtaine will reveale. Enter Albert.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who's that? ha!
Some gentle hand, I hope, to bring me comfort.
Or if it be my death, tis ſweetly ſhaddowed.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Have ye forgot me ſir?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My Aminta?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She ſir,
That walks here up and down an empty ſhadow,
One that for ſome few houres
But wanders here, carrying her own ſad Coffin,
Seeking ſome Deſart place to lodge her greifes in.

sp.speaker: Alb.
