sp.l: Sweet ſorrow welcome, welcome noble griefe;
How got you this faire liberty to ſee me?
For ſorrows in your ſhape are ſtrangers to me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to counſell ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye are ſtill more welcome;
For good friends in afflictions give good councels.
Pray then proceed.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Pray eate firſt, ye ſhew faint;
Here's Wine to refreſh ye too.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I thank ye deere.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Drinke again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Here's to our loves.
How, turn and weepe!
Pray pledge it: this happineſſe we have yet left,
Our hearts are free. Not pledge it? why,
And though beneath the axe this health were holy,
Why doe ye weep thus?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I come to woe ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To woe me Sweet? I am woe'd and wonne already,
You know I am yours. This pretty way becomes ye.
But you would deceive my ſorrows; that's your intent.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I would I could, I ſhould not weep, but ſmile.
Do ye like your Meat and Wine?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Like it?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Do you like your liberty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: All theſe I well may like.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Then pray like her that ſent'em.
Doe ye like wealth, and moſt unequal'd beauty?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Peace, indeed you'l make me angry.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Would I were dead that aske it,
Then ye might freely like, and I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What like, and who? adde not more miſery
To a man that's fruitfull in afflictions.
Who is't you would have me like?
Who ſent theſe comforts?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I muſt tell.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Be bold.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But be you temperate.
If you be bold I die. The young fair Virgin;
(Sorrow hath made me old.) O hearken,
And wiſely harke, the Governeſſe daughter:
That Star that ſtrikes this Iſland full of wonder,
That blooming ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: She ſent it: and with it,
It muſt be out, ſhe dotes on ye,
And muſt enjoy ye: elſe no joy muſt find ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And have you the patience to deliver this?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: A ſiſter may ſay much, and modeſtly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A Siſter?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Yes, that name undid ye;
Undid us both: had ye nam'd wife, ſhe had fear'd ye;
And fear'd the ſin ſhe followed; She had ſhun'd, yea
Her Virgin modeſty had not touch'd at ye.
But thinking you were free, hath kindled a fire,
I feare will hardly be extinguiſht.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Indeed I played the foole.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O my beſt ſir, take heed,
Take heed of lies. Truth though it trouble ſome minds,
Some wicked minds, that are both darke and dangerous:
Yet it preſerves it ſelfe, comes off pure, innocent,
And like the Sunne, though never ſo ecclipſ'd,
Muſt breake in glory. O ſir, lie no more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ye have read me a faire Lecture,
And put a ſpell upon my tongue for fayning.
But how will you counſell now?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye muſt ſtudy to forget me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be patient.
Be wiſe and patient, it concerns ye highly.
Can ye lay by our loves? But why ſhould I doubt it?
Ye are a man, and men may ſhift affections,
Tis held no ſin. To come to the poynt,
Ye muſt loſe me; many and mighty reaſons.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Heare me Aminta,
Have you a man that loves you to, that feeds ye,
That ſends ye liberty? has this great Governeſſe
A noble ſonne too, young, and apt to catch ye?
Am I becauſe I am in bonds, and miſerable,
My health decay'd, my youth, and ſtrength halfe blaſted,
My fortune like my wayning ſelfe, for this deſpiſ'd?
Am I for this forſaken? a new love choſen,
And my affections, like my fortunes wanderers?
Take heed of lying, you that chid me for it;
And ſhew'd how deep a ſin it was, and dangerous.
Take heed, your ſelfe, you ſwore you lov'd me deerly;
No few, nor little oathes you ſwore Aminta,
Thoſe ſeal'd with no ſmall faith, I then aſſur'd my ſelfe.
O ſeek no new waies to cozen truth.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I do not.
By Love it ſelfe I love thee,
And ever muſt, nor can all deaths diſſolve it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why do you urge me thus then?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: For your ſafety,
To preſerve your life.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My life I do confeſſe is hers,
She gives it,
And let her take it back, I yeild it.
My loves intirely thine, none ſhall touch at it;
None, my Aminta, none.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Ye have made me happy,
And now I know ye are mine. Fortune, I ſcorn thee.
Go to your reſt, and Ile ſit by ye;
Whilſt I have time Ile be your mate, and comfort ye,
For onely I am truſted: you ſhall want nothing,
Not a liberty that I can ſteal ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: May we not celebrate our loves Aminta?
And where our wiſhes cannot meet

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: You are wanton,
But with cold kiſſes Ile allay that feavor;
Look for no more, and that in private too.
Believe me I ſhall bluſh elſe.
But let's conſider, we are both loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let's in, and prevent fate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You do well to ayre us Ladies, we ſhal be muſty elſe.
What are your wiſe wils now?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are very cranck ſtill.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: As cranck as a holy Fryer, fed with hayl-ſtones.
But do ye bring us out to baite, like Buls?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Or are you weary of the charge ye are at?
Turn us abroad again, let's jog Ladies;
We are groſſe, and courſe, unfit for your ſweet pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Knock off our ſhoos, and turn's to graſſe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are determined
Still to be ſtubborn then: it well becomes ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: An humour Lady that contents a priſoner.
A ſullen fit ſometimes ſerves for a ſecond courſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye may as well be kind,
And gain our favours; gain meat, and drink,
And lodging to reſt your bones.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: My bones have bore me thus long,
And had their ſhare of pains, and recreations;
If they fayl now, they are no fayr companions.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Are ye thus harſh to all our ſex?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We cannot be merry without a Fidler.
Pray ſtrike up your Tabors, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: The fools deſpiſe us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We know ye are very hungry now.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Yes, tis very wholſome Ladies;
For we that have groſſe bodies, muſt be carefull.
Have ye no piercing ayre to ſtir our ſtomacks?
We are beholding to ye for our Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why ſlaves, tis in our power to hang ye.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Very likely.
Tis in our powers then to be hang'd, and ſcorn ye.
Hanging's as ſweet to us, as dreaming to you.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come, be more courteous.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Do, and then ye ſhal be pleas'd, and have all neceſ|ſaries.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Give me ſome Ratſ-bane then.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: And why Ratſ-bane, Mounſier?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: We live like vermin here, & eate up your Cheeſe,
Your mouldy Cheeſe, that none but Rats would bite at;
Therefore tis juſt that Ratſ-bane ſhould reward us.
We are unprofitable, and our Ploughs are broken;
There is no hope of Harveſt this yeere, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have all content.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I, and we'l ſerve your uſes.
I had rather ſerve hogs, there's more delight in't;
Your greedy appetites are never ſatisfied;
Juſt like hungry Camels, ſleeping or waking
You chew the cud ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: By this hand we'l ſtarve ye.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Tis a Noble courteſie.
I had as liefe ye ſhould famiſh me, as founder me,
To be jaded to death is onely fit for a hackney.
Here be certain tarts of tar about me,
And parcels of potargo in my Jerkin,
As long as theſe laſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Which will not laſt ever.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then we'l eate one another like good fellows,
A ſhoulder of his for a hanch of mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Twill be, as we'l dreſſe it Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Why ſure ye are not men.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Ye had beſt come ſearch us,
A Seaman is ſeldome without a ſalt Eele.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am bad enough,
And in my nature a notorious wencher;
And yet ye make me bluſh at your immodeſty.
Tell me good Maſter, didſt ever ſee ſuch things?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I could like 'em though they were lewdly given,
If they could ſay no; but fie on 'em,
They gape like Oyſters.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Well, ye may hang, or ſtarve us;
But your commanding impudence ſhall never feare us.
Had ye by bluſhing ſigns, ſoft cunnings, crept into us,
And ſhew'd us your neceſſities: we had met your purpoſes,
Supply'd your wants. We are no Saints Ladies;
I love a good wench, as I love my life,
And with my life I will maintain my love:
But ſuch a ſordid impudence Ile ſpit at.
Let's to our dens again. Come noble Maſter.
You know our minds Ladies:
This is the faith in which we'l die. Exit Tib. and Maſt.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I doe admire 'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are noble fellows,
And they ſhall not want, for this.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: But ſee, Clarinda comes. Enter Clarinda.
Farewell, Ile to my charge.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Bring out thoſe priſoners now,
And let me ſeee 'em, and heare their buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will, Maddam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I hope ſhe hath prevail'd upon her brother.
She has a ſweet tongue, and can deſcribe the happineſſe
My love is ready to fling on him.
And ſure he muſt be glad, and certain wonder
And bleſſe the houre that brought him to this Iſland.
I long to heare the full joy that he labours with.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Bleſſe thy Divine beauty.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mirror of ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Ever ſpringing brightneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, ſtand up Gentlemen, and leave your flatte|ries.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shee cals us Gentlemen, ſure we ſhall have ſome meat now.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am a mortall creature,
Worſhip Heaven, and give theſe attributes
To their Divinities. Methinks ye look but thin.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O we are ſtarv'd, immortall beauty.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We are all poor ſtarv'd knaves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Neither liberty nor meat Lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: We were handſome men, and Gentlemen, & ſweet men,
And were once gracious in the eyes of beauties,
But now we look like rogues;
Like poore ſtarv'd rogues.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would ye do if ye were to die now?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas we were prepar'd. If you will hang us,
Let's have a good meale or two to die with,
To put's in heart.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or if you'l drown us,
Let's be drunk firſt, that we may die merrily,
And bleſſe the founders.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye ſhal not die ſo haſtily.
What dare ye do to deſerve my favour?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Put us to any ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Any bondage,
Let's but live.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Wee'l get a world of children,
For we know, ye are hainouſly provided that way;
And ye ſhal beat us when we offend ye;
Beat us abundantly, and take our meat from us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Theſe are weak abject things, that ſhew ye poor ones.
What's the great ſervice ye ſo oft have threatned,
If ye might ſee me, and win my favour?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That buſineſſe of diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: O, Ile tell ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: and ſo will I.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And I,
Pray let me ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good, no confuſion.
We are before a Lady that knows manners;
And by the next, meat I ſhall eate, tis certain.
This little Gentlewoman that was taken with us

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your Captains ſiſter, ſhe you mean.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I, I, ſhe's the buſineſſe that we would open to ye.
You are couſned in her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, what is't you would open?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is no ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good ſirs, how quick you are.
She is no ſiſter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is his.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Peace I ſay.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Faith, ſweet Lady,
She is, as a man would ſay, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or, as ſome new tranſlators read, his.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And why he ſhould delude you thus,
Unleſſe he meant ſome villany? theſe ten weeks
He has had her at Sea for his own propes appetite.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His Cabin-mate, Ile aſſure ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No ſiſter, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No more then I am brother to your beauty.
I know not why he ſhould juggle thus.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do not lie to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: If ye find me lie, Lady, hang me empty.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How am I fool'd!
Away with 'em, Juletta, and feed 'em
But hark ye, with ſuch food as they have given me.
New miſery!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nor meat, nor thanks for all this. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Make 'em more wretched.
O I could burſt! curſe and kill now,
Kill any thing I meet. Juletta, follow me,
And call the reſt along.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We follow Maddam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: I muſt be gone now, elſe ſhe may ſuſpect me;
How ſhall I anſwer her?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Tell her directly.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: That were too ſudden, too improvident;
Fires of this nature muſt be put out cunningly,
They'l waſte all come neere 'em elſe.
Farewell once more.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Farewell.
And keep my love entire.
Nay kiſſe me once again, me thinks we ſhould not part.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O be wiſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nay, one kiſſe more.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Indeed you'r wanton; Enter Clarinda, Juletta, Crolale, Hippolita.
We may be taken too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Out thou baſe woman.
By Heaven Ile ſhoot 'em both.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Nay ſtay, brave Lady, hold;
A ſudden death cuts of a Nobler vengeance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I made Bawd to your laſcivious meetings?
Are ye grown ſo wiſe in ſin?
Shut up that villaine: and ſirra,
Now expect my utmoſt anger.
Let him there ſtarve.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I, mock at your miſchiefes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tie that falſe witch unto that Tree,
There let the ſavage beaſts
Gnaw of her ſweetneſſe, and Snakes
Embrace her beauties; tie her, and watch
That none relieve her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: We could wiſh ye better fortune Lady,
But dare not help ye.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Be your own friends, I thank ye.
Now onely my laſt audit, and my greateſt, Enter Raymond.
O Heaven, be kind unto me,
And if it be thy wil, preſerve.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Who is this?
Sure tis a woman; I have trod this place,
And found much footing: now I know tis peopl'd.
Ha, let me ſee! tis her face.
O Heaven! turn this way mayd.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O Raymond, O brother.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Her tongue to: tis my ſiſter; what rude hand!
Nay kiſſe me firſt, O joy!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Fly, fly deere brother,
You are loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A man, a man, a new man.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: What are theſe? Enter Juletta, Crocale, Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: An Enemy, an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Diſpatch him,
Take him off, ſhoot him ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: I dare not uſe my ſword, Ladies,
Againſt ſuch comely foes.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O brother brother!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Away with 'em, and in darke priſons bind 'em.
One word replyd, ye die both.
Now brave mother follow thy Noble Anger,
And Ile help thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enteer Roſsella, Clarinda, Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: I am deaf to all your intreaties: ſhe that moves me
For pity or compaſſion to theſe Pirates,
Digs up her fathers, or her brothers Tombe,
And ſpurns about their aſhes.
Couldſt thou remember what a father thou haſt once,
Twould ſteele thy heart againſt fooliſh pity.
By his memory, and the remembrance of his deere embraces,
I am taught, that in a Noble cauſe revenge is Noble;
And they ſhal fall the ſacrifices to appeaſe
His wandering Ghoſt, and my incenſed fury.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The new come priſoner to?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Him to. Yet that we may learn
Whether they are the ſame, or neere ally'd
To thoſe that forc'd me to this cruell courſe,
Better their poore allowance, and permit'em
To meet together and confer,
Within the diſtance of your eare; perhaps
They may diſcover ſomething that may kill
Deſpaire in me, and be a means to ſave 'em
From certain ruine.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: That ſhal be my charge.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Yet to prevent
All hope of reſcue: for this new come Captain
Hath both a ſhip and men not far off from us,
Though ignorant to find the onely Port,
That can yeeld entrance to our happy Iſland,
Guard the place ſtrongly, and ere the next Sunne
Ends his diurnall progreſſe, I wil be
Happy in my revenge, or ſet 'em free. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, Hippolita. A Table furniſht.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: So ſerve it plentifully,
And loſe not time to enquire the cauſe;
There is a main deſign that hangs upon this bounty.
See the Table furniſht with Wine too,
That diſcovers ſecrets which tortures cannot open:
Open the doores too of the ſeverall priſons,
And give all free entrance into this room.
Undiſcover'd I can here marke all. Enter Tib. Maſt.
Here's Captain careleſſe, and the tough Ship-maſter,
The ſlaves are noſ'd like Vultures
How wilde they look.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ha, the myſtery of this,
Some good Hobgoblin riſe and reveale.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I am amazed at it: nor can I ſound the intent.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Is not this Bread,
Subſtantiall bread, not painted?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: But take heed,
You may be poyſoned.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am ſure I am famiſht;
And as the wiſe man ſays,
Gripes the guts as much as any Minerall.
This may be Treacle ſent to preſerve me
After a long faſt: or be it Vipers ſpittle,
Ile run the hazzard.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We are paſt all feare, Ile take part with ye.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Do: and now yfaith, how d'e feel your ſelfe?
I finde great eaſe in't. What's here?
Wine, and it be thy will;
Strong luſty Wine. Well, fooles may talke
Of Metridate, Cordials, and Elixars.
But from my youth this was my onely Phyſick.
Here's a colour, what Ladies cheek,
Though ceruſs'd over, comes neere it?
It ſparkles too: hangs out Diamonds.
O my ſweet heart, how I will hug thee,
Again, and again! They are poor drunkards,
And not worth thy favours,
That number thy moyſt kiſſes in theſe Chriſtals.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: But Mounſiuer,
Here are Suckets, and ſweet diſhes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Tuſh, boys meat,
I am paſt it; here's ſtrong food fit for men:
Nectar, old lad. Miſtris of merry hearts,
Once more I am bold with you.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Take heed (man)
Too much will breed diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Haſt thou liv'd at Sea
The moſt part of thy life, where to be ſober
While we have Wine aboord, is capitall treaſon;
And doſt thou preach ſobriety?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: prethee forbeare,
We may offend in it; we know not for whom
It was provided.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am ſure for me: therefore footra,
When I am full, let 'em hang me, I care not.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: This has been his temper ever. Enter Albert, Aminta, Raymond, Lamure, Mor|rillat, Franvile, ſeverally.
See, provoking diſhes, candid Eringoes,
And Potatoes.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Ile not touch 'em, I will drink;
But not a bit on a march, Ile be an Eunuch rather.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Marry, who you will;
I keep my text here.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Away, Ile be drunke alone;
Keep off rogues, or Ile belch ye into ayre;
Not a drop here.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: Deere brother, put not in your eyes ſuch anger;
Thoſe looks poyſon'd with fury ſhot at him,
Reflect on me. O brother looke milder, or
The Chriſtall of his temperance
Will turn 'em on your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir have ſought ye long
To finde your pardon: you have ploughed the Ocean
To wreak your vengeance on me, for the rape
Of this faire virgin. Now our fortune guides us
To meet on ſuch hard terms, that we need rather
A mutuall pitty of our preſent ſtate,
Then to expoſtulate of breaches paſt,
Which cannot be made up. And though it be
Far from your power to force me to confeſſe,
That I have done ye wrong, or ſuch ſubmiſſion
Failing to make my peace, to vent your anger;
You being your ſelfe ſlav'd, as I to others:
Yet for your ſiſters ſake, her bleſſed ſake,
In part of recompence of what ſhe has ſuffered
For my raſh folly; the contagion
Of my black actions catching hold upon
Her purer innocence: I crave your mercy,
And wiſh however ſeverall motives kept us
From being friends while we had hope to live,
Let death which we expect, and cannot fly from,
End all contention.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Drink upon't, 'tis a good motion;
Ratifie it in Wine, and tis authenticall.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: When I conſider
The ground of our long difference, and look on
Our not to be avoyded miſeries,
It doth beget in me I know not how
A ſoft religious tenderneſſe; which tels me,
Though we have many faults to anſwer for
Upon our own account, our fathers crimes
Are in us puniſht. O Albert, the courſe
They took to leave us rich was not honeſt,
Nor can that friendſhip laſt, which vertue joyns not.
When firſt they forc'd the induſtrious Portugals,
From their Plantations in the happy Iſlands.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: This is that I watch for.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: And did omit no tyranny, which men
Inured to ſpoyle and miſchiefe could inflict,
On the griev'd ſufferers; when by lawleſſe rapine
They reapt the harveſt, which their labours ſowed;
And not content to force 'em from their dwelling,
But layd for 'em at Sea, to raviſh from 'em
The laſt remainder of their wealth; then, then,
After a long purſuit, each doubting other,
As guilty of the Portugals eſcape,
They did begin to quarrell, like ill men;
(Forgive me piety, that I call em ſo)
No longer love, or correſpondence holds,
Then it is cimented with prey or profit:
Then did they turn thoſe Swords they oft had bloodied
With innocent gore, upon their wretched ſelves,
And payd the forfeit of their cruelty
Shown to Sebaſtian, and his Collonie,
By being fatall Enemies to each other.
Thence grew Amintas rape, and my deſire
To be reveng'd. And now obſerve the iſſue:
As they for ſpoyle ever forgot compaſſion
To women, (who ſhould be exempted
From the extremities of a lawfull war)
We now, young able men, are faln into
The hands of women; that, againſt the ſoft
Tenderneſſe familiar to their ſex, Enter Crocale.
Will ſhew no mercy.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: None, unleſſe you ſhew us
Our long loſt husbands.
We are thoſe Potugals you talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.l: Stay,
I met upon the Sea in a tall ſhip
Two Portugals, famiſht almoſt to death.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Our ſhip by this Wine.
And thoſe the rogues that ſtole her,
Left us to famiſh in the barraine Iſlands.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Some ſuch tale they told me,
And ſomething of a woman, which I find,
To be my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Where are theſe men?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I left 'em,
Suppoſing they had deluded me with forg'd tales,
In the Iſland where they ſayd
They had liv'd many years the wretched owners
Of a huge maſſe of treaſure.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The ſame men: and that the fatall muck
We quarreld for.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They were Portugals you ſay.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: So they profes'd.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: They may prove ſuch men as may ſave your lives,
And ſo much I am taken with faire hope,
That I will hazard life to be reſolv'd on't:
How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: My ſhip lies by the rivers mouth,
That can convey yee to theſe wretched men,
Which you deſire to ſee.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Back to your priſons,
And pray for the ſucceſſe: if they be thoſe
Which I deſire to finde, you are ſafe;
If not, prepare to die to morrow:
For the world cannot redeem ye.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How ever, we are armd
For either fortune, Exit.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: What muſt become of me now
That I am not diſmis'd?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: O ſir, I purpoſe
To have your company.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Take heed wicked woman,
I am apt to miſchiefe now.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You cannot be ſo unkind,
To her that gives you liberty.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: No, I ſhall be too kind, thats the devil on't;
I have had ſtore of good wine: and when I am drunk,
Joane is a Lady to me, and I ſhall
Lay about me like a Lord: I feele ſtrange motions:
Avoid me temptation.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Come ſir, i'le help yee in. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: VVhat may that be
That mooves upon the Lake?

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still it drawes neerer,
And now I plainly can deſcerne it.
Tis the French ſhip.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: In it a woman,
VVho ſeemes to invite us to her,

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Still ſhe cals with ſignes of Love to haſten to her;
So lovely hope doth ſtill appeare:
I feele nor age nor weakneſſe.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Though it bring death,
To us tis comfort: and deſerves a meeting.
Or els fortune tyrd with what we have ſuffer'd,
And in it overcome, as it may be,
Now ſets a period to our miſery. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What dreadfull ſounds are theſe?

sp.speaker: Amin
sp.l: Infernall Muſick,
Fit for a bloody Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It ſeemes prepar'd
To kill our courages, e're they divorſe
Our ſoules and bodies.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: But they that feareleſſe fall,
Deprive them of their triumph.

sp.speaker: Aminta
sp.l: See the furies,
In their full Trym of cruelty.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Tis the laſt
Duty that I can pay to my dead Lord,
Set out the Altar, I my ſelfe wilbe
The Prieſt, and boldly do thoſe horrid Rites
You ſhake to think on: lead theſe Captaines neerer,
For they ſhall have the honour to fall firſt
To my Sebaſtians aſhes: and now wretches,
As I am taught already that you are,
And lately by your free confeſſion,
French pirats, and the ſons of thoſe I hate,
Even equall with the devil; here with horror,
What tis invites me to this cruell courſe,
And what you are to ſuffer; no Amazons we,
But women of Portugall, that muſt have from you
Sebaſtian and Nicuſa; we are they
That groan'd beneath your fathers wrongs:
VVe are thoſe wretched women,
Their injuries purſu'd, and overtook;
And from the ſad remembrance of our loſſes
We are taught to be cruell; when we were forc'd
From that ſweet ayre we breathed in, by their rapine,
And ſought a place of being; as the Seas
And winds conſpird with their ill purpoſſes,
To load us with afflictions, in a ſtorme
That fell upon us; the two ſhips that brought us,
To ſeek new fortunes in an unknown world
Were ſevered: the one bore all the able men,
Our treaſure and our Jewels: in the other,
We women were imbarq'd: and fell upon,
After long toſſing in the troubled maine,
This pleaſant Iſland: But in few moneths,
The men that did conduct us hither died,
We long before had given our husbands loſt:
Remembring what we had ſuffred by the French,
We took a ſolemn Oath never to admit
The curs'd ſociety of men: neceſſity
Taught us thoſe arts not uſuall to our ſex:
And the fertile Earth yeelding abundance to us,
We did reſolve thus ſhapt like Amazons
To end our lives; but when you ariv'd here,
And brought as preſents to us our own Jewels;
Thoſe which were boorn in the other ſhip,
How can ye hope to ſcape our vengeance?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: It boots not then to ſwear our inocence?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Or that we never forc'd it from the owners?

sp.speaker: Ray
sp.l: Or that there are a remnant of that wrack,
And not far off?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: All you affirme, I know,
Is but to win time; therefore prepare your throats,
The world ſhall not redeem ye: and that your cries
May find no entrance to our eares,
To moove pitty in any: bid lowd Muſick ſound
Their fatall Knels; if ye have prayers uſe 'em quickly,
To any power will own yea; but ha! Enter Crocale, Sebaſtian, Nicuſa, Tibalt.
Who are theſe? what ſpectacles of misfortun?
Why are their looks
So full of Joy and wonder?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Oh! lay by
Theſe inſtruments of death, and welcome
To your armes what you durſt never hope to imbrace:
This is Sebaſtian, this Nicuſa Maddam:
Preſerv'd by miracle: look up deer ſir,
And know your own Roſſellia: be not loſt
In wonder and amazment; or if nature
Can by inſtinct inſtruct you what it is,
To be bleſſed with the name of Father,
Freely injoy it in this faire Virgin.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: Though my miſeries,
And many years of wants, I have indur'd,
May well deprave me of the memory
Of all joyes paſt; yet looking on this building,
This ruind building of a heavenly forme
In my Roſſella; I muſt remember, I am Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: O my joyes!

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.l: And here,
I ſee a perfect modell of thy ſelfe,
As thou wert when thy choyce firſt made thee mine:
Theſe cheecks and fronts though wrinkled now with time
Which art cannot reſtore: had equall pureneſſe,
Of naturall white and red, and as much raviſhing:
Which by fayre order and ſucceſſion,
I ſee deſcend on her: and may thy vertues
Winde into her forme, and make her a perfect dower:
No part of thy ſweet goodneſſe wanting to her.
I will not now Roſſellia aske thy fortunes,
Nor trouble thee with hearing mine;
Thoſe ſhall hereafter ſerve to make glad howers
In their relation: All paſt wrongs forgot;
I am glad to ſee you Gentlemen; but moſt,
That it is in my power to ſave your Lives;
You ſav'd ours when we were neer ſtarv'd at Sea,
And I deſpaire not, for if ſhe be mine?
Roſsellia can deny Sebaſtian nothing.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: She do's give up her ſelfe,
Her power and joyes, and all, to you,
To be diſcharged of 'em as to burthenſome;
Wellcome in any ſhape.

sp.speaker: Sabaſt.
sp.l: Sir in your looks,
I read your ſute of my Clarinda: ſhe is yours:
And Lady if it be in me to confirme
Your hopes in this brave Gentleman,
Preſume I am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: O Happy houre!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O my deer Aminta;
Now all our feares are ended.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Here I fix: ſhe's mettle,
Steele to the back: and will cut my leaden dagger,
If not uſ'd with diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: You are ſtill no changling.

sp.speaker: Sabaſt.
sp.l: Nay,
All look cheerfully, for none ſhalbe
Denyd their lawfull wiſhes; when a while
We have here refreſht our ſelves; wee'l returne
To our ſeverall homes; and well that voyage ends,
That makes of deady enemies faythfull friends.
